column4: the kernel raid driver keeps a RAID superblock on the disk/partition that you use, and it stores info about the raid array in it. So a raid array created with md should work with any md
Excellent. So at that point I'd only need to have the raid config file and use a mkraid, right?
you shouldn't even need the raid config file, although I think it does have some effect on detecting arrays on system startup
and I've always used mdadm, I don't know if the classic raid tools do it differently
